Answers.MP Summary: A command line interface for SQLite version 3
Answers.Most Similar TLDR Task: Execute an SQL statement against a database and then exit
Top-3 Scripts:
so_49820669: #!/bin/bash
sqlite3 <<EOF
.mode csv
.import file.csv tbl
.save file.db
EOF

so_5776660: #!/bin/bash
./bin/sqlite3 ./sys/xserve_sqlite.db <<!
.headers on
.mode csv
.output out.csv
select * from eS1100_sensor_results;
!

Explanations about Options.-e(M):
Execute the statement and quit. The default output format is like that produced with
 --batch. See Section 4.2.2.1, “Using Options on the Command Line”, for some examples.
 With this option, mysql does not use the history file.
Explanations about Options.-u(M): The user name of the MySQL account to use for connecting to the server.

Answers.Most Similar TLDR Task: Execute SQL statements in a script file (batch file)
Top-3 Scripts:
au_405897: for SQL in *.sql; do DB=${SQL/\.sql/}; mysql $DB < $SQL; done

for SQL in *.sql; do DB=${SQL/\.sql/}; mysql -u user --password=11111 $DB < $SQL; done"
Top-3 Similar Questions: au_405897: How can I import multiple .sql files into MySQL?

Explanations about Options.-c(M):
Specifies that psql is to execute the given command string, command. This option can
 be repeated and combined in any order with the -f option. When either -c or -f is
 specified, psql does not read commands from standard input; instead it terminates
 after processing all the -c and -f options in sequence.

Answers.Most Similar TLDR Task: Execute a single SQL query or PostgreSQL command on the given database (useful in shell scripts)
Top-3 Scripts:
so_33525611: cat my_file.txt | \
awk -F" " -v  Q="'" '{print "INSERT INTO my_table VALUES(" Q$1Q " , " Q$2Q ");" }' | \
psql postgres -1

Explanations about Options.-t(M):
Determine the number of columns the input contains and create a table. Columns are
 delimited with whitespace, by default, or with the characters supplied using the -s
 option. Useful for pretty-printing displays.

Answers.Most Similar TLDR Task: Specify column delimiter character for the -t option (e.g. "," for csv); default is whitespace

Explanations about Options.-name(M):
This option is supported, but POSIX conformance depends on the POSIX conformance of
 the system's fnmatch(3) library function. As of findutils-4.2.2, shell
 metacharacters (`*', `?' or `[]' for example) will match a leading `.', because
 IEEE PASC interpretation 126 requires this. This is a change from previous
 versions of findutils.
